text: 12 oz can. Pours a clear copper pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt and lager yeast, along with some caramel. Caramel malt flavor with some bready character before a semi sweet finish.

Can. Anger with one finger head. Medium body with toasted caramel, bread, light nuts. Very well balanced with the hops. Its not a beer that screams greatness at the onset, but I could drink a ton of this. Extremely well done.
Backlog entry: I had this one at the brewery. Its a solid beer, nothing too unusual or stand-out.
Slightly hazy orange with thin white head. Smells like fruity wet bran. Honey grainy in a medium thick body. Nice mellow bitter finish.

12 Oz can.. Pours hazy orange with a creamy, off-white head and almost no lacing. Mild aromas of bready malt, oats and herby, nobel hops. Flavor has little malt up front, goes quickly to herby hop, almost thyme, then some bready malt finishing with malt and grain sweetness and herby hop linger. Medium body with a creamy mouthfeel and active carbonation and some cloying sugars. Overall, quite quaffable and mellow.

Clear golden with a thin tight white cap. Big Munich malt nose thats biscuity and slightly corny. Crisp and bready nutty/toffee/German malty flavor thats a touch grassy and very balanced. Just a malty but smooth and delicious Oktoberfest beer.
12 oz can at home. Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have toasted malts, caramel, bready, mild floral notes, earthy, decent enough Oktoberfest.

Great aroma with medium carbonation, the color is a dark amber from the various malts. Complex flavors arise from this beer from the first sip. Bready with toasted nuts make this beer very enjoyable. An excellent first lager from Revolution.

Draught. Pours a clear amber orange with a quickly fading off white sudsy head. Aroma is of toffee, hint of spice and citrus. Taste is of toffee, maple syrup, earthy, floral. Watery mouthfeel, medium carbonation.

Can. Bread crust aroma. Bready malt with caramel and bright citrus notes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught pint at The Looking Glass in Janesville, WI, October 12th. Poured a dark somewhat brackish amber with minimal head, though some could be created with a bit of swirling...at first almost not aroma to be ascertained, just a dry husky leaf-like character; with several minutes a bit of caramel malt does come through and some resin...much the same experience in the mouth, with just a dry, dusky and bitter nothingess, but again it improves fairly dramatically with a few minutes sitting, and just enough sweetness comes out, and the ending dryness becomes less harsh. Medium-bodied, fairly strong carbonation. One of the better arguments Ive experienced recently for not serving too cold, this I would have rated in the low 2s after the first couple of sips, but it became quite drinkable (if not among my favorites in the style by any means) in 15 minutes.
Tap at not sure where I am. Fine copper pour. Nose is faint caramel and toasted malt. Tastes of toast, malt, caramel, earth, hint of currants, some sweet Apple to finish. Fine for style
Orange amber. Fruity orange malt with hops. Flavor is fruity toasted malt and balanced hops. One of the best Oktoberfests Ive had in awhile.

Nice head, but more of an amber rather than traditional red (personally for this kind of beer, I prefer traditional). Aroma is caramel malt and hints of toast and hops. Flavors similar to nose, on sweet side, good carbonation. Bodys a bit thin. Good enough finish. An ok Okfest.
Amber nutty oktoberfest. Very good. Medium body, a little American hops. Sweet, nutty, earthy
A bit hoppier than usual for style but a nice nutty Oktoberfest is hard for me to turn down. Good stuff.

Bronze color with a taller ecru colored head. Some hops aromas (a touch citric) and hint of caramel and toasted malt. Light sweet flavors. A bit nutty and some floral hops mixed in. Not real clean, not toasty and refreshing, Im quite certain if a brewery in my fatherland were to bring this one to market there might be a revolution. 10/12
Draft at Dark Horse, 11/17/15. Great win by my Terps! Clear orange color without much head or lace. Nice malty presence on a small hop note. Average carbonation. Solid beer.

Nice pour, orange yellow with small thin head that went away after a sip. Malt, hops, alcohol, barley, corn, yeast in the aroma. Taste follows, very balanced. Nice hop and pine presence, balanced well with sweetness and a bitter aftertaste. Nice

12 oz can, poured into a shaker pint at ~40 degrees F.

Appearance: Pours a beautifully clear dark-honey amber, and forms a massively fluffy slightly off-white head that leaves lacing on the glass just by diminishing.

Smell: Glazed doughnut with pepper sprinkled atop,

Taste: Thick bread, sweet caramel, slight hints of toffee, white and black pepper, vague suggestions of earth and wood oils. A bit of a floral tinge at the finish.

Mouthfeel: Smooth, medium, and sharp.

Overall: I enjoyed this marzen. I would drink it again.
Can. At Beatrix for brunch. Clean grainy Oktoberfest. Malty, lightly bitter, clean. Standard for the style.
can. a solid, easy to drink Octoberfest beer. Though not my favorite style, it was pretty nice

A touch sweet and hoppy but a good medium bodied Oktoberfest. A little extra carbonation enhances the slight spice from the hops. The slight caramel malt almost wants to get sticky until the hops crisp it up and add a touch of spice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark orange with some red. Big bubbled white head. Looks very thin, I guess I am not used to lagers. Smells of barley, grain. Kind of nice smell as a change of pace. Really clean grain taste in the front, absolutely no aftertaste. This is a good lager, but I am just so unfamiliar with the style at this point.

Cans at the Galaxy Oktoberfest. Pours a light amber with ample head. Aroma is toast, nuts, mild spice, caramel. and toffee with slight dank hops. The taste is similar with the malts really shining through and balancing with the slightly more hopped beer for the style. Moderate carb, light body, easy to drink. Tasty all around.

12oz can from Savor Pint: amber pour, off-white head that disappears quickly leaving a ring. aroma of sweet caramel, cereal. tastes are moderately sweet cereal, little floral, nutty. not my favorite style, but seems like a good one.

Aroma of caramel, fresh bread. Nice clear deep orange colr. Huge tan head, lingers a bit. Creamy rich malt up front. Charred caramel and some notes of toffee. Bitterness fills in quick, slightly off balance as sweetness dissipates quickly. Finish is on the bitter side but not off putting. slightly watery mouth feel. O.k.
Might be my favorite Oktoberfest. Perfect blend and flavor. Light caramel flavor with that hint of yeast. Love this beer and this time of year...
12 oz Can -- Pours deep amber with a very thin off-white head. Aromas of roasted malt, almond, caramel, and some mild bandage. Falls a little flat taste wise. A bit thin but pleasent.
Caramel and toast make up the aroma. Taste starts with sweet caramel and a toast like flavor to carry into the middle. It then finishes with herbal hops

From a can, nice clear amber orange pour, minimal white head. Aroma is fresh bread, hints of caramel. Flavor is mild malts.
This is really a better beer than the rated score. You could sit down and drink these all day. A really nice beer.
Can. Nice cooper brown. Has a standard Okoberfest taste. Nice nutty malt. With a hint of Grassy hops.
On tap. Cooper color with one finger head. Biscuit, caramel aroma. Taste is more caramel malt, very smooth and easy to drink.

Pour on tap at the brewery, clear amber pour with white head, aroma brought notes of toasted bread, biscuit, toffee into some slight grass, herbal hops with an earthy note, slight grainy-ness to it as well. Taste was a mix of grain, grass, biscuit into a bit of toffee, caramel, toasted bread and burnt toast, some spice, grass, finishing slightly dry.
Mahogany pour with a tan head. Aroma is not much. Taste is a light caramel malt. Ok beer.

Poured from 12 ounce can purchased at Delhi Liquor Store (fka One Stop Party Shop), tasted on October 26, 2014. Slightly cloudy amber hue, moderate toasted malt/sugary nose, smooth toasted malt flavor--not much hoppiness but whats impressive about this beer is that it has none of the harshness/off flavors found in lesser examples of the style. It doesnt have the depth of flavor of Moerlein Fifth & Vine Oktoberfest but Im giving it the same score. Really nice brew.

Can from Sake Taniguchi (World Beer Market). Good roasty nose, some tropical fruit, caramel. Medium amber color, thin tan lace. Roast malt initial, a little burst of chocolate and berries, cake dough, and light final hop bitterness. Thin-medium body. Pleasant. Somewhat surprising flavors in mid palate. Tasty enough but not really special.

Very slightly sweet honey aroma. From a can this has a really nice sparkling pour with a big head. Looks a orangish pale lager. Taste is quite strong but it seems to have lots of that fest feel to it. Could have a few more manners. A little bit medicinal, you can tell this stuff is 6% +. So they make fest beer year round now? OK, so be it, technology can do everything, we are so smart, heheh. Yessir, goes down pretty easy but that little kick keeps reminding you that it a higher % beer. OK overall.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Sample, 4 ounces, draught, drunk at Revolution Brewing - Milwaukee Avenue, trip to Chicago, savoured on September 27 2014; eye: coppery, clear, tiny ring of off-white head, light lacing; nose: malt, sugar, slight fruity; mouth: malt, sugar, slight fruity, light acridness, malty finale with acrid presence, medium body, average carbonation, mildly sweet, lightly harsh texture; overall: correct
 
FRANÇAIS
 
Échantillon, 4 onces, en fût, bue chez Revolution Brewing - Milwaukee Avenue, voyage à Chicago, savourée le 27 septembre 2014; il : cuivrée, limpide, petit anneau de mousse blanc cassé, légère dentelle; nez : malt, sucre, très léger fruité; bouche : malt, sucre, très léger fruité, légère âcreté, finale maltée avec présence dâcreté, corps moyen, carbonatation moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture légèrement râpeuse; en résumé : correct

Pours a clear copper-orange color with a medium off-white head that recedes steadily to a film. Short strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel and hops. Medium-bodied with flavors of burnt malt, caramel and earthy hops. The finish is sweet with a malty aftertaste. Decent overall.

Pours clear amber with sticky lacing. Mild aroma is a little musky with earth and baking spice notes. Palate is medium-full with a musky caramel flavor. Good structure and a nice finish. Very good for the style.

On tap @ the brewpub. This years batch is 5.7%. Light copper/deep gold. Fruity caramel aroma and flavour, hints of chocolate, moderately sweet with excellent malt structure and a nice hoppy finish. Excellent.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Distinct in this style for its balanced caramel malt and lack of overall sweetness, gaining subtle brown sugar elements and finishing with understated hops. Well-balanced through the medium length.
Pour is dark amber with a small off-white head. Aroma and flavor of bready dough, light caramel, herbal hops, rye spice, and soft pretzels. Finish is slightly more spice/hop.

Can into a tulip. Deep golden orange, quite clear, light white head. Light honey, some floral notes, some spice. Slightly damp hay. Light bitterness upfront, trailing off through the finish. Round sweetness predominates. Mid to light body, mild carbonation. Some acidity. Quite a long aftertaste. Quite good.

On tap poured into a pilsener glass. The aroma is that of toast, some citrus, some grass, and earthy note, and a hint of spice. It pours a clear brown-orange color with a soft, whitish head that retains a decent surface layer and a medium thick, mostly dense, ring. It leaves behind rings of snowy lace on the glass. The taste is a nice balance between medium, malty sweet and medium, spicy bitter. The creamy texture is complimented by a fizzy carbonation. The medium body contains notes of grass, earth, and spice with a caramel undertone. Its slightly dry and finishes clean with flavors of dry citrus peel, spice, and caramel. Theres also a hint of cough syrup to the finish. The aftertaste is slightly astringent and holds earth notes as well as spice.
Can pour. Clear copper with a white head. The aroma has some fruity and some carrot cake qualities. The taste is somewhat sweet, but remains earthy. Lighter body and medium carbonation.

Not my style of beer. Very strong malt flavor and smells like a lager. Slightly sweet finish. Pours deep orange in color. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours mostly cleat light amber, slight thin head, good lacing. Aroma toasted malt, caramel, slight fruity, slightly floral. Taste very rich malty, sweet, toasty, slight caramel, fruity and floral, almost very slight pineapple juice. Mouthfeel medium-full body medium carbonation, clean lager feel, sweet finish. Overall very nice beer for style, one of the best American versions Ive had, may be a bit too sweet though.

Draft 9/16/14 (The Town)-Pours a clear copper with a decent sized head. Aroma of malt, caramel, and slight hops. Taste of the same. This medium bodied brew is well balanced but a little light in the flavors. Not my favorite style but decent.

Six pack of cans from weilands in columbus Ohio. Revolution Oktoberfest is a dark copper brew with a thick head of tan foamed big bubbles. Nose is crisp malt and generous hops. Taste is medium malty with a decent tang of hop over the top. hints of daramel. a very nice beer. good example of the marzen style but refined. very nice oktoberfest beer.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2015 Blind rating: This is a tasty one. Its very clear amber w/ a foamy head. Its clean and very floral w/ lots of hops. Its slightly sweet w/ crisp carbonation. This is a well made beer across the board. 

Original Rating (3.5):This is a decent Oktoberfest thats quite drinkable at the expensive of being a little light on flavor. It is a clear orange color w/ a small white head. Its nose is nice and malt--mostly caramel--w/ a hint of floral hops. Taste is on the light side but w/ a similar and pleasant balance of malt and hops as is in the nose. This is a medium bodied beer, just slightly sweet w/ fine but vigorous carbonation. It finishes crisply w/ some lemon zest and sugar lingering on the tongue. This is actually on the strong side for an Oktoberfest, Id say, but it drinks like a much lighter beer, which is a nice change of pace for a style that is frequently oversweet and heavy.

Ok, admittedly not my favorite style of beer here, but Revolution is awesome so here goes anyway. Fresh can dated August 17th poured into a pub glass. The beer pours a clear copper with a finger of off white head and not much lacing. Aroma is malty up front. Caramel, toffee, and hay are all pretty strong. There is kind of a burnt caramel smell there too. Nice. Immediately the beer has a strong toffee, burnt brown sugar, caramel flavor. There is a lot of big bread flavors..something like a dark rye and a grassiness as well. The beer sticks around on your tongue and roof of your mouth for a while isnt too heavy. I could drink quite a few if the mood was right. Overall a very nice surprise as I am not a huge Oktoberfest fan. Revolution did it right.

Revolution Oktoberfest Revolution, brought to you by the Department of Redundancies Department. Draft sample at Cincy Beerfest 2014 on Fountain Square. Pours a clear orange with a small off-white head. Notes of sweet and caramel and toasty malts, grass, straw, mild spice, and crackers. Light-bodied, with high carbonation and a sweet mouthfeel. Maybe a bit highly rated within the style, because it struck me as a fairly average example. Not bad, just fine.

Incredibly smooth beer here. Great flavor from a great brewery. One of the top Oktoberfest beers out there would get this almost every time

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can poured into pint glass (US sized). This is a very solid Oktoberfest lager. Slight head on the pour which ends up dissipating. Surprisingly minimal in carbonation, which allows some of the flavor to come out in a smoother body. So not a bad thing, in essence. Has a heavy bready, lager yeast feel here with a slight toffee note in there. A good beer for when the weather turns to Fall.
Nice copper color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of caramel malt, some fruit/floral, & spice; Flavor of slight roasted sweet malt, caramel, floral hops, and spice; Pretty decent.
Rich deep orange, a bit of head. Big beery aroma; some yeast, roasted malt, spice. Rich nutty flavor; some pretzel. Light refreshing mouthfeel, lingering aftertaste. Really good.

This is a great entry into the Oktoberfest scene. A little roasted hops like you get in a typical Oktoberfest, and fairly mild so its widely palatable. I still dont really like Oktoberfest, but it seems like Revolution has joined the ranks with Great Lakes as my favorite. Its a good solid Oktoberfest.

Rich deep copper, bronze and amber coloured body with a thick, three centimetre tall just off-white head. Aroma of alcohol, malt, nuts, earth, hop bitterness, caramel and a bunch of nuts. Medium-bodied; Dense, chewy, pungent malt notes throughout with a deep sweetness and alcohol flavour right behind. Aftertaste shows a lot of complexity and a very strong malty note with a nut and earth bite that lasts quite a while. Overall, a nice and potent beer with no flavours lacking - a strong beer, but good in nearly every way! I sampled this twelve ounce can purchased from Binnys in Chicago (South Loop), Illinois on 21-August-2013 for US$1.67 sampled at home in Washington on 20-December-2013.
Aroma is fruit, grains, bread and a hint of citrus. The flavor is citrus, fruit/berries, earthy notes, malts and a tart finish.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a pale amber color with a white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma. Fruity malty sweetish grainy flavor with weak hoppy hints. Has a sweetish malty grainy caramel finish.

12 ounce can into dimpled mug; no canning date, but from 2013. Pours slightly hazy orange copper color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Light spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of caramel, toffee, toast, biscuit, pear, apple, floral, herbal, light pepper, light nuttiness, and yeast earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance of malt and yeast notes; with solid strength. Taste of caramel, toast, biscuit, toffee, floral, pear, apple, herbal, light pepper, light nuttiness, and yeast earthiness. Lingering notes of caramel, toast, biscuit, toffee, herbal, floral, pear, apple, light pepper, light nuttiness, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice balance and robustness of malt and light earthy hop flavors; with a fair amount of yeast esters with zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth and lightly slick mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a very nice Oktoberfest style. All around good balance and robustness of malt and moderate yeast ester flavors; and extremely smooth to drink. A very enjoyable offering.
Draft at Revolution Brewing, Chicago. Pours hazy light amber with a small off white head. Aroma of malt and fruits. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Tap at Revolution Brewing, Milwaulkee Ave, Chicago. Poured a clear medium amber with a round white head. The aroma is very weak malt. The flavour is medium bitter with a malt liqourice hop nutty palate and a long bitter finish.
Draft at Hawkeyes. Poured dark range with light ring of white. Sweet malty aroma. Light carb med body. Sweet malty taste. Bleh nothing special.
Yeasty aroma. Light orange hue. Doesnt look full. Average taste but light on the palate. I added 1 point from beigh from a can.
Can. Amber pour with a small head. Spices, apple and malt aromas. Vanilla and caramel.

From a can. Pours clear amber with decent off white head. Smell is sweet caramel malts, some light ripe fruit, doughy. Flavor was smooth caramel, medium sweet, light light spice, touch of hops, faint fruity. Nice Oktoberfest.
Tap at the brewery. Medium amber color, not much nose. Most surprising to me was the presence of coriander flavor in the beer. Not bad, but not my go to choice for an Oktoberfest beer

I havent tried many Octoberfests because of my IPA snobiness (which Im outgrowing), but I enjoyed this one. A very pleasant aroma for a lager. Tastes slightly sweet, malty with nice hops bitterness in the background. Very drinkable.

From a can poured in a shaker. Appearance is fizzy slightly orange amber. Flavor is thin, fairly carbonated, sweet, slightly bitter with moderate alcohol note. Nothing special, floral hop notes on finish. Unexceptional Oktoberfest, was built up like this was a really good one, but it didnt impress. Still drinkable though.
12oz can. Clear copper pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of malt and lager yeast, along with some caramel. Caramel malt flavor with some bready character before a semi sweet finish.

12 oz. can. Orangish amber pour with an off white head. Aroma of caramel malt, some cider aromas. Flavor is rich, malty. Big sweet caramel and toffee notes, some german hop notes. This is solid, nice, full bodied and delicious. Finishes somewhat sweet.

Its a solid and true-to-style Oktoberfest offering and relatively easy to drink. Not my favorite style, but fairly enjoyable all the same. If youre into Oktoberfest beers, or even darker lagers this would be worth trying.

Pours clear reddish-amber with a medium white head that disappears quickly. Aroma is spice, caramel, yeast. Taste is quite sweet, more than I expected. Mouthfeel is light and highly carbonated. Very mild finish. Almost zero bitterness. No much in the way of hops. The sweetness combined with the spice and caramel maltiness kind of remind me of a belgian, but theres something lager-like as well. Maybe the yeast? Perhaps Im just unfamiliar with this style. Note to self: drink more Octoberfests.

Pours Clear amber. 3 fingers of frothy off white head that dissipates quickly to a cap. A ton of carbonation. No lacing. Nose is very earthy and nutty with some spice and caramel. Mouth is slightly bitter with a unique hoppy quality. Some sweetness with a slight malt backbone. A very good Oktoberfest.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2015 12oz can. Clear amber color. Thin, sort of bubbly khaki head. Couple loose dots of lace, nothing really sticks. Nice citrusy, kind of mango-y hop nose, some tropical fruit. Faint, but there, along with the caramel malt. Medium body, smooth crisp lighter carbonation. Lightly dry finish. Head fades to nothing. Moderate bitter taste, minimal sweet. Light spice. Hoppy for an oktoberfest, but I like it. 7/2/6/4/13Rerate, 9/16/15: 12oz can, filled 8/05/2015, labeled 5.7%. Mildly hazy amber orange red color. Thin off-white head, leaving decent reaches of lace. Maltier, caramel, and nuttiness, and a bit of vegetable. Moderate sweet taste, light to moderate bitter. Bit of a peppery hop on the end, but not nearly as hoppy as I remember. Medium-plus body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Mild slick finish. Decent american oktoberfest.

A really good traditionally brewed American ofest...great aroma reminds me of what Germany smells like. Everything to me in this beer is great for an ofest. I wish she had just a tad more lasting carbonation ... Great beer great brewery... Go cubs!!! Oh and add a soft pretzel and u in heaven

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can to half-pint glass (shared with the Mrs.). Looks good for the style; a mostly transparent copper with thin off-white head that dissipates into lacing pretty quickly. Smells and tastes of dough and caramel with a solid mouthfeel. A decent Oktoberfest.
Pours light red. Draft. Not much head.  Light and grainy smelll.  Earthy and Carmel bites.  Pretty good for the style
Superb example of a balanced and thoughtful Oktoberfestk Marzen. A nice strong beer for fall and beyond, with a nice hit of spices on the nose and a caramel finish. A great local Chicago beer.

22oz bottle via trade. Clear light amber with an off white head. Aroma of bread dough, caramel and light herbal hop. Flavor is bready malt, sweet caramel and lightly bitter. Medium body with mild carbonation. Pretty solid beer for the style, just a tad sweet.

12oz can. Poured hazy brown with a thin head. Fresh spicy aroma. Bold fresh flavour lots of depth and malt character this beer has withstood the test of time. Great palate and depth very drinkable I like it.

Bomber thanks to Pawola! Pours a cloudy amber/orange with a large khaki head. Aroma of caramel and toffee malts, yeast, slight vanilla, and hops. Taste similar to aroma very well balanced and drinkable for the style which is typically not one of my favorites. Pretty nice!

22 oz. bottle served in a mug. Seems pretty appropriate for the beer. 

A: Pours a clear copper color with a one finger height of solid off-white foam forming on the pour. The retention is awesome and it slowly recedes down the the glass leaving some sticky sheets of lace.

S: Lagery yeast and pale malts. A slight dose of caramel with subtle spices. There is a mild hop backing to it, but its far in the periphery. 

T: Caramel and pale malts with a slight spiced backing. Light green hops with some lager yeast and malty sweetness. The finish is clean with a light hint sweetness.

M: Medium bodied with a medium carbonation. Clean finish.

O: A very solid representation of the style, but it doesnt wow me. Very solid malty sweetness and the light hop backing adds another depth of flavor. At 4.99 this a great value and would buy again if i was in the right setting.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-09-2012
Had this at the 2012 Great American Beer Fest in Denver, Colorado. It was a bit to sweet.

12oz can picked up at the local shop... pours a mostly transparent but somewhat darker amber hued consistency with a lively feel to it and topped with a quickly settled soapy white head... aroma of toasty caramel malt and darker grains with a hint of grass... flavors are more of the same with semi-sweet dark grains, caramels, and dark fruit. lighter than medium bodied with a moderate level of carbonation.  touch of very light grassy bitterness on the backend.
A nice oktoberfest, especially to battle against the proliferation of pumpkin beers. Lots of bronze golden color. Earthy, malt flavors.
Revolutions Oktoberfest offering. Less carbonated but very standard Oktoberfest flavor. Sweet malts and a smooth finish.
Pours medium amber. Scent of fresh grain and malts on the nose. Medium bodied and slightly crisp. Could dring this on a nice fall day.

Very good representation of a Marzen.  I really liked the aroma and the way this beer looked in the glass.  Medium on the hops but lots of nice spice notes.  Pretty clear bronze color with a smallish white head and some lacing.  Taste is where it really shines.  Lots of caramel, toffee, bread, and some other spices that I couldnt quite put my finger on, but where tasty and unique.  Maybe some coriander and even some other stuff comes through as it warms a bit in your glass.  I will definitely buy more of this and savor it through October.  I love these guys.

Can from pantanap...thanks Kan! - Pours clear amber with a thin white head. Nose is lightly spiced dry bready malt. Taste is about the same, though its thinned out a bit and maybe slightly watery. Finishes with some soured bread malt and a touch of herbal hops. Thinnish with decent carbonation, but falls a bit flat.

Pours copper with a white head.  Aroma has some light toastiness, caramel, nuts, and grain.  Malty, nutty flavor is what strikes me as dominant, along with bread, some spice, and some floral notes.  There are some hoppy flavors as well.  I detect some sweetness in here.  Medium bodied with a nutty and bready aftertaste.  Pretty easy to drink.  Nothing really negative to note here, but this one isnt terribly exciting either.

This is probably the most german tasting of all the Oktoberfests Ive had from the USA.  Very much tastes like a classic german okto with a malty and bready taste and some bitterness.  Very impressed.

Bottle. Pours a clear, copper-amber color, little in the way of head or lacing. Nose is malt, bread and almost a pie spice aroma (reminiscent of some holiday ales). Really nice mouth, with some caramel and bread, light hops bitterness. Finishes pretty clean with a lingering slight bitter note. A very nice example of a Märzen. The RBC beers are Batting .1000 for me so far. ;-)

Clear copper with modest off-white head / Sweet nose of toast and spun sugar / Light to medium body, sweet and somewhat syrupy, with some bitterness on the fair finish / Simple, clean flavors of toast and spun sugar, with citrus notes / Mediocre.

Mostly clear, copper-gold colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing throughout. Aroma is some caramel and a lightly toasted crackers. Some floral, fruity hops and a bit grainy. Flavor is similar. Sweeter crackers and a tad grainy with a moderate caramel. A light toast with some more floral and fruity hops before this finishes with a light, but defined crisp bitterness that provides a solid balance and light dryness. Medium length, floral bitter and toasty caramel aftertaste. Medium, smooth, easy drinking body with a moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid Oktoberfest. Well put together and tasty.

Had this on tap at The Bavarian Lodge in Lisle. A great local version of an Oktoberfest marzen. Very smooth and very drinkable. A testament as to why I wish they brewed Oktoberfest beers year round.

damayor---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
dark see through amber color, smell of yeast, dough. balanced maltiness in flavor with a bread dryness
This is a seriously well done marzen.  Great robust earthy flavor.   Only complaint is it is a bit sticky and sweet, but other than that its near perfect for style.

Bottle purchased at Binnys, surprisingly havent had this until recently at Great Taste of the Midwest. Pours a translucent amber/golden brown in color with a small white head. Nose is a solid traditional marzen, there is toasted malt and some breadiness. There is also faint hops and some light spice. The flavor is a little hoppier than I would typically prefer, but it doesnt really detract from the beer. In addition to noble hops, I get toasted malt, some honey, and light spice. Light to medium mouthfeel, light carbonation, no booziness, and a moderate finish. Pretty solid domestic interpretation of a marzen, I will gladly grab another bottle or two of this to enjoy during football season. Great value at $5 for a 22 oz.

Pours clear amber with sticky lacing. Mild aroma is a little musky with earth and baking spice notes. Palate is medium-full with a musky caramel flavor. Good structure and a nice finish. Very good for the style.

On tap at Revs pre-Great Taste party held at the Essen Haus in Madison, WI.. Served to plastic but showed a bright, coppery color, decent, off white head foam, and good cling to the curtainy lacing. The nose was lightly lagerish, some toastiness, and light sweetness. Medium bodied with soft carbonation, the flavor presented a hop bitterness that was more pronounced than most Marzens that Ive tried, but it complemented well, and I liked it!
A suprisingly well-done maerzen form the US. No diacetyl, beatiful layers of sweet, bready malt, and a facefull of noble hops, but properly executed.

On tap at the brewery as a free sample during the brewery tour before it was bottled (or available in their tap room)..  Clear red/orange color with a small white head.  Aroma is full of grains, but it surprised me as being the most spicy and hoppiest Oktoberfest beer Ive tried.  Taste is slightly bitter.  This is the only Marzen/Oktoberfest Ive truly enjoyed.

Tap sample. Poured clear brownish color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate earthy and toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

On tap at GABF 2011. Pours a clear copper color with a medium white head. The aroma is sweet toast and leaves. The flavor is a mellow and smooth Marzen; honey, some light bitter hops, bready, very smooth and clean. Nice.

Enjoyed on tap at Revolution Brewery in Chicago, IL with some friends prior to seeing the band F*ed Up.  Didnt take notes while drinking, but this was a decent offering from one of my least favorite styles.  Definite nutty / malt presence and I remember this being a bit tart, and also remember that this was towards the bottom of the keg which may have altered the taste a bit.  Still pretty decent though.

this pours a nice dark orange color

very good aromas with malts, grains, and blood oranges. fairly straightforward, but balanced and aromatic 

medium bodied with a good plumpness to the feel. Smooth and round as well with good malty flavors dominating

this is a good and solid oktoberfest. While there are grain tones to it, they dont dominate and instead we get some malty goodness

Had this one on draft at the brewpub.  Bready malty smell.  Grain is just oozing out of this one.  Malt flavor with a little caramel at first.  Hop & malt finish.  Very very German.  Kind of boring if you ask me.
Draft... Dark clear orange with a light tan head... Light nose, generic lager... tastes sweet, a touch boring but drinkable, ok

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2013 Draft at revolution, Pours amber with white head. Nose nice and toasty, nutty malt aroma with nice floral and spicy noble hops. Flavors nicely nutty and toasty malts, good malt backbone, big floral noble hop character, slightly fruity finish, nice really drinkable fest beer. Great malt character, Only issue is the finish is a tad sweet as its pushing a little high for the style.

I took a break from trying a lot of delicious homebrews at the HOPS Oktoberfest to try this out.  Nice pour - a clear copper body with a respectable head.  The aroma was sweet malt, toasty, with some light hopping.  The hops were slightly more pronounced in the flavor, balancing out the beer nicely.  Very good.

Draft on tap at the brewpub during Oktoberfest at Revolution (Chicago, IL). Pours a decent copper hue, some fire to it, a light haze, with a moderate offwhite head atop that dies to a thicker film, laces small. Aromas are bready malts, biscuits, a touch of sweeter toffee. Faint spiciness and a touch of floral hopping. Initial is bready and biscuity malts, a touch of sweeter malts behind, a light floral hopping with a touch of spice. Light dryness into the finish, lingering bready and biscuity malts. Spice really never gets to what Id like it, as it falls back to a bit more bland than Im used to. Still, its nice.. and better than most other Oktoberfests around these parts. Decent hopping, malt slanted obviously on the palate, with a dry and lingering mellow sweet finish. Not bad.

I am only recently starting to like Oktoberfest beers more.  This beer is a great example of what Oktoberfest should be.  Pours copper with an off white head.  Crisp flavor, nice sweet malt.  Clean and easy to drink.  I could have this stuff year round.

Draft. We had a keg of this bad boy for our Homebrew club Oktoberfest. Pours a very attractive burnished bronze with fluffy offwhite head. Nose is toast, crisp notes of wheat bread and beer. Crisp hop notes. Text book take on the style, fermentation is super clean. Good body and CO2 levels. Revolution is definitely doing the right things...

tap.  bready, doughy, must malts.  light caramel, coffee backing.  decent amoutn of tropical fruit hoppiness for the style.   for the style, which im not typically a big fan of, its good.  and well suited for the chicago fall season.

Draught at the brewpub.   Darker copper with some honey and orange hues.   lasting head.   Nice looking stuff.   Malty and sweet with a definite toffeeish caramel note that is almost english in character and seems a little out of place in an oktoberfest.   Hops provide a little tanginess and bite but the malt runs the show.   Bready and lightly toasty as well.   The aroma is moderate and mostly displays the same malt character.   A little too sweet/toffeeish to me.   I dont think Id do well with a liter of this.

Poured from a growler picked up at the brewpub. Mostly clear, copper-gold colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a moderate lacing throughout. Aroma is some caramel and a lightly toasted crackers. Some floral, fruity hops and a bit grainy. Flavor is similar. Sweeter crackers and a tad grainy with a moderate caramel. A light toast with some more floral and fruity hops before this finishes with a light, but defined crisp bitterness that provides a solid balance and light dryness. Medium length, floral bitter and toasty caramel aftertaste. Medium, smooth, easy drinking body with a moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid Oktoberfest. Well put together and tasty.

On tap at the brewpub.Pours a nice clear copper color with modest white head. Aroma shows caramel malt, crunchy grain, and flowery hops with some bitter notes. Flavor is similarly caramel-malty up front, crisp, grainy, biscuity, a little dry, small hints of floral and fruity notes, rounded off with a modest but well-focused hop bitterness. Medium body with lively, tingly palate. A dead-on, textbook festbier.
